abstracts.cdata!:
The audit concurs, by and large, with
            the Implementation Completion Report's ratings of
            satisfactory project outcomes, modest institutional
            development impacts, and satisfactory performances by both
            the Bank and Borrower, but downgrades sustainability to just
            likely. This assessment confirms a number of OED lessons
            from the education sector. Countries that have limited
            literacy rates, and few schools may benefit from a strategy
            that simultaneously pursues, both supply-side (school
            construction, teacher training), and demand-side (public
            campaigns to enroll girls) interventions. However, even if
            enrollment increases, potential gains may be lost upon
            students drop out. School authorities must be sensitized to
            the needs and problems of rural students, and actively try
            to prevent drop out, particularly among those not yet
            functionally literate. Furthermore, by itself, student
            enrollment does not guarantee acquisition of basic skills.
            It is also necessary to use classroom time wisely, ensure
            that textbooks are available, provide in-service teacher
            training, and allow for systematic supervision, i.e.,
            attention to education quality. The strategy of employing
            female teachers may fall short of expectations due to
            budgetary constrains, and the low numbers of qualified women
            willing to work in rural areas. Recruiting women who already
            live in rural areas, even if they have a relatively limited
            education, may be a sound way to increase the number of
            female teachers.

6074130.trustfund:
TF020254-BASIC EDUCATION PROJECT FOR THE
            REPUBLIC OF YEMEN,TF020600-FINNISH GENERAL CONSULTANT
            TRUST FUND,TF032903-EUROPE AND MIDDLE EAST -
            EDUCATION (EGYPT, YEMEN, JORDAN),TFM20254-BASIC EDUCATION PROJECT FOR THE
            REPUBLIC OF YEMEN,TFS20254-BASIC EDUCATION PROJECT FOR THE
            REPUBLIC OF YEMEN

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome was
            satisfactory, sustainability highly likely, though
            institutional development impacts are modest. Among the main
            lessons, the importance of clearly defining the expected
            outcomes of administrative entities is reinforced, to be
            accomplished through specific terms of reference with
            detailed roles, and responsibilities, and, developed for
            implementation prior to loan effectiveness. In addition, it
            is recommended that periodic reviews, and implementation
            progress be pursued, with the subsequent report issuance for
            consideration by the funding agencies, and borrower. And, in
            the absence of strong procurement capacity, particularly in
            light of large civil works, and procurement of goods, and
            consultant services, it would have been wise to carry out a
            procurement capacity assessment, implemented during
            appraisal, or prior to effectiveness. This could have solved
            specific issues, and avoided implementation delays. Once
            again, the importance for community involvement at an early
            stage of the project is emphasized, by adequately
            structuring their assistance in planning, supporting, and
            implementing their roles, and responsibilities, potentially
            avoiding delays in site selections, and reducing unit costs,
            while ensuring project sustainability. Other lessons
            emphasize the need to define technical assistance based on a
            preliminary institutional assessment; assess project impacts
            using clear monitoring indicators; and, provide adequate
            funding for teachers supervision.

18154423.trustfund:
TF020600-FINNISH GENERAL CONSULTANT
            TRUST FUND,TF020254-BASIC EDUCATION PROJECT FOR THE
            REPUBLIC OF YEMEN,TF032903-EUROPE AND MIDDLE EAST -
            EDUCATION (EGYPT, YEMEN, JORDAN)

repnme.cdata!: Republic of Yemen - Basic Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the project is
            twofold, namely, to increase the school participation rate
            of girls in rural areas and to lay the foundation for
            improving the quality of basic education. The project will:
            (a) increase the participation rate of girls in rural areas
            by providing adequate classrooms and improving their
            utilization, and by promoting the recruitment of female
            teachers; and (b) improve the quality of basic education
            system for the training of teachers in service and through
            capacity-building for the development of a unified
            curriculum, a new textbook series, and standardized student
            achievement tests.
